--- John Arrowwood <jarrowwx@...> wrote:
> But do you have any way of tying the network XML to
> the run XML?  

Not explicitly, no. 

If you haven't already, check out Colin's proposed
neat-run-output.xml in the Files>NEAT XML section. 
He's got timestamps for each generation under a
"save-time" attribute, though it would probably be
best to have a tag or attribute noting the start time
for the run, and use that as a unique id for the run
itself.  Then every network generated as a result of
that run could contain either an attribute or tag with
that timestamp as well, as a way of correlating the
two.

Right now, the neat-run-output.xml that Colin's put
out there can contain all the individuals and all of
their specific information, but I think we'd prefer to
store the XML for individuals as separate files, while
using the run XML as an index.
 
> If you see 
> that there was a network that did something
> anomalous in the run, can you 
> identify the xml of the network in question?  

Sure, every network was an id.  But it's not unique
across all runs.  So, as I suggest above, a timestamp
would probably be the best way to correlate a network
and a run.  So, for example, we could talk about
"network #432 from the run started on
2004-04-01@9:00:00", or something similar.

If individuals are loaded up for use in the initial
population of a second or third run, that information
should be added to the XML as well.

The network XML that I posted should be considered a
starting point...I hope.  For instance, currently it
doesn't contain any information about the activation
function of nodes, which we would most likely want to
include.

Derek
